poem:
**Zaria Objects**

A man  
goes north—Zaria—  
and listens with his eyes.

Cloth,  
embroidered breath,  
leather worked soft as history  
under the thumb.

He gathers  
what is leaving,  
labels it,  
lets it travel:  
four hundred small facts  
to a museum.

Later  
bronze, stone—  
his hands still learning  
the wind's old patterns.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "David Heathcote obituary My uncle David Heathcote, who has died aged 94, was an artist, art historian and teacher. After studying at the Slade School of Fine Art in London, he taught for a long period in Africa, including in northern Nigeria at Ahmadu Bello University in Zaria, where he was head of art history. While in Zaria he began interviewing Hausa craft workers and documenting their work. In the late 1960s and 70s he amassed an important collection, including clothing and embroidered dress (on which he wrote his PhD), as well as leatherwork and crafts, understanding that these skills and techniques were fading. Most of that collection was acquired by the British Museum – 400 or so objects, now much studied – and in 1976 works were featured in The Art of the Hausa exhibition at the Commonwealth Institute in London and at The Art of African Textiles at the Barbican in 1995. David’s writings on crafts were widely published and in 1978 he made a short documentary film about Hausa art. His own art was profoundly influenced by his time in Africa and he made sculptures in bronze and stone, surreal ad hoc assemblages as well as collage and drawing alongside his main medium of painting. He exhibited at the Museum of Mankind in London in 1989 and in numerous galleries in London, Paris and Nigeria. Canterbury Christ Church University, in Kent, where David taught for many years, has three of his sculptures, and some of his early". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
